Chapter 18: The Bodhisattva leaves home
The Bodhisattva made the following pledge:
"Tonight is the last night that I spend in a house with a woman.
Henceforth, I never again stay with a woman in a house."
Tired of making music and dancing, the women had fallen asleep.
They lay sprawled, some stark naked and disheveled
others with spittle formed on their lips, murmuring some gibberish.
Seeing them in this state, the prince found them all ugly.
Meanwhile, Siddhartha's foster mother, Maha-prajapati (Skye dgu'i bdag mo), dreamt that an eclipse swallowed up the moon,
that the sun rose and set in the east,
and that a huge crowd of people prostrated themselves at the prince's feet while she herself was sobbing uncontrollably.
Yashodhara (Grags 'dzin ma) dreamed eight dreams:
her house's ridge beam splintered,
her bed shattered,
her bracelets broke,
her teeth fell out,
her braid untwined,
the glory of her house faded,

and the sun set in the east.
The Bodhisattva fell asleep and had five dreams.
The earth itself was his bed and Mount Meru (Ri rab) his pillow;
his right hand sliced into the Western Ocean and his left into the Eastern Ocean, while his outstretched legs tread the bottom of the Great Ocean;
a very long stalk of grass spiraled out of his navel and went skyward;
a swarm of black-headed white birds surged at his feet and licked them. Varicolored birds darted forward from the four directions and clustering in front of him, turned to one uniform color; and
he walked upon a mountain of sludge without getting a speck of soil or stain.
The Bodhisattva's heart filled with joy.
“These dreams are a sign that before long I shall attain the wisdom which is unsurpassable.”
When Yashodhara related her dreams to Siddhartha he, to soothe her fears, advised her not to give credence to dreams.
The Bodhisattva knew, without the shadow of a doubt, that he would soon have to leave for the wilds,
but to save the queen from worry he announced his plans in veiled terms.
She caught what he was alluding to immediately.
“Sire,” she pleaded, “wherever you may go, take me with you!”
Deep down, the prince was always thinking of the sphere of ultimate peace.
But he promised Yashodhara that he would take her along.
He was just twenty-nine years old.
A little while later, Indra (Brgya byin), Brahma (Tshangs pa) and a host of other gods appeared to the Bodhisattva. They were aware of his intention
and knew that the time for leaving home had come.
"Rise, Prince, it is time to leave for forests wild!"
"How can I? the Bodhisattva asked, "The army has surrounded the palace!"
Indra replied: Just as, you in former times got others to the forest unhindered, Brahma, myself and the other gods will do the same for you.
Delighted to hear this, the Bodhisattva leapt out of bed.
Indra put all the inhabitants of the citadel into an overpowering sleep,
while the yaksa Pañcika (gnad sbyin Lnga rtsen) propped the colossal ladder—which even five hundred men together could barely lift—against the castle wall.
The Bodhisattva climbed swiftly down and landed at the foot of the wall.
He ran to wake his equerry: "Chandaka (Mdun pa), quick, bridle my horse Kanthaka (Sngags ldan),
I'm off to the forest!
Your Highness, this is not the time for going to gardens!
Besides, nobody's upset with you.
Nobody knows you to have a single enemy.
So why do you want to ride off [sneak off] in the dead of night?
"Don't talk to me like that!" the Bodhisattva cried, "Do as I tell you!"
But Chandaka, pretending to be afraid of the dark, would not fetch the prince's stallion.
The Bodhisattva insisted but the equerry turned a deaf ear.
In the end, lest their argument wake the guards,
Siddhartha himself went off to look for his steed.
Kanthaka sensed that the Prince wished to go to the Ascetics' Forest (Dka' thub kyi gnas).
Alarmed, it arched its neck, reared and bucked.
Softly caressing the high-spirited creature's forehead, the Bodhisattva whispered in its ear:
"Kanthaka, I beg one last favor of you: take me without delay to the Ascetics' Forest!
Once Awakening has been attained, through the liberating rains of contemplation, I will shower [all good things] on all beings."
The stallion then stood still and allowed Siddhartha to fix on the bridle.
Indra summoned four young champions of the world of the gods, Tira ('Gram), Upatira (Nye 'gram), Parna (Lo ma), and Parna-paridhita (Lo ma gyon pa).
To the Bodhisattva, who was curious to have proof of their strength, the god of gods proudly declared:
"These athletes are capable of both lifting and carrying the earth itself,
including the four oceans,
the mountain ranges,
and all the trees and plants on it."
The Bodhisattva then placed his foot firmly upon the ground but the four champions, pulling together and with all their might, could not make him budge.
They felt utterly astonished by this.
The wonder of it all spread to Chandaka, who had been watching.
He approached his master.
The Bodhisattva swung into the saddle and pulled the equerry up behind him.
When the four gods lifted the horse up into the sky,
the palace's protector gods fell to weeping.
Fearing that his father's heart would break if he were to leave the city by one of its other gateways and without a last farewell,
the Bodhisattva proceeded towards the eastern portal.
But Shuddhodana (Zas gtsang) was locked in sleep.
“Father,” said the Bodhisattva, “I have no wish to manifest the least disrespect toward you.
If I am leaving, it is so that this world's beings may, once and for all, be freed from the tortures of suffering.”
The watchman, Shakya Mahanaman (Ming chen) arrived just in time to hear these words.
“Prince,” he sobbed out, “You cannot be leaving us!”

“Shakya Mahanaman,” replied the Bodhisattva, “If, over the course of three immeasurable kalpas, I have had the strength to endure unbelievable hardships for the sake of achieving perfect Awakening which will let me help all beings—
why, today, would I remain at home?
I am off to the Ascetics' Forest, that's a certainty!”
He expressed himself so resolutely that Shakya Mahanaman did not have the effrontery to repeat his plea openly.
Instead, he cried out: "King Shuddhodana's and all the Shakyas' long-cherished hopes and plans
Have, tonight, gone up in smoke,"
The head guardsman cried thus, as he tried in vain to shake Yashodhara and the other queens out of their enchanted stillness.
Although he called to king Shuddhodana, the king did not awaken.
He ran from pillar to post, screaming at the top of his voice. But he might as well have bayed at the moon: no one stirred, not a single voice replied.
Lifting up the horse's hooves, the four gods took the Bodhisattva across the sky.
Respectfully shrinking away from the prince on the right, the gods of the world of Form took their leave;
while on the left, respectfully shrinking away, the gods of the world of Desire, loaded with offerings, took their leave,
and appropriately, Indra and Brahma went in front of Kanthaka.
From the height of the firmament, gods and goddesses, loaded with heaps of offerings, descended.
A shower of flowers sweetened the air, which trembled to the sound of cymbals.
“This is perfect,” said the Bodhisattva, thanking the gods.
But they lingered, begging him to remember them upon attaining the unsurpassable awakening.
He promised he would.
